column1: Clichy-sous-Bois (French pronunciation: ​[kliʃi su bwɑ]) is a commune in the eastern suburbs of Paris
column2: France. The majority of its population is made up of African heritage
column3: making it one of the immigrant majority banlieues (urban suburbs) of Paris. The commune is not served by any motorway
column5: or railway and therefore remains one of the most isolated of Paris's inner suburbs. Clichy-sous-Bois is where the 2005 civil unrest started

column1: The commune has an area of 3.95 km2 (1.53 sq mi) with 1.1 km2 (0.42 sq mi) of woods. The woods are remnants of the Bondy wood (Forêt Départementale de Bondy
The commune is 15 kilometres (9.3 mi) from central Paris.
The name of Clichy-sous-Bois comes from Roman Cleppius
Flint tools from the Neolithic have been found here.
Clichy en Aulnois belonged to the lords of Livry in the early Middle Ages.
Subject to the Knights Templar in the 13th century
column2: Clichy subsequently passed into possession of the Knights Hospitaller order. Until the 16th century
column3: it was a hunting resort of the French kings. In the 18th century
column4: it belonged to the Duc d'Orléans. In 1820

column2: a part of the territory of Clichy-sous-Bois was detached and merged with a part of the territory of Livry-Gargan and a small part of the territory of Gagny to create the commune of Le Raincy.
Clichy was affected by the Franco-Prussian war.

column1: Clichy-sous-Bois has a high unemployment rate compared to the rest of the country
column2: about 20% and 40% of the people under 25 years old (source : INSEE).

column1: The suburban riots of October 2005 originated in Clichy-sous-Bois after the death of two young boys who had been escaping a police control. Then the riots spread to other communes of the department
column2: and then to virtually every major urban area in France.

column1: As of 2015 the youth unemployment rate was 40%.
As of 2009 33% of the commune's residents were foreign nationals
column2: higher than both the departmental average and the French national average.

column1: Clichy-sous-Bois is not served directly by any station of the Paris Métro
column3: or suburban rail network. The closest station to Clichy-sous-Bois is Le Raincy – Villemomble – Montfermeil station on Paris RER line E[1]. This station is located in the neighboring commune of Le Raincy
column4: 3.2 km (2.0 mi) from the town center of Clichy-sous-Bois. There is also a T4 Tramway stop at Gargan which is 1.1 km from the town centre. The tramway terminates at the Bondy station for RER-E2
column5: which is only 3 stops to Paris Gare du Nord ( via correspondence at Magenta station) The only direct transport in and out of Clichy-sous-bois is by bus (for example the 601AB bus if you are coming from "Le Raincy-Villemonble-Montfermeil" station).

column1: Due to the lack of a rail link
column2: it was claimed the time on public transport to the city centre can be 1.5 hours  but this predates the tramway opened November 2006. A new branch of the T4 Tramway was scheduled to open in 2017
column4: passes through the heart of Clichy-sous-Bois.

column1: As of 2007 the unemployment rate was around 20%. It was close to 50% in the housing estates defined by The Economist as "the worst."
In 2015 a police station was established.
In 2007 the voting turnout for the presidential election in Clichy was 82%. The voter registration had increased by less than 20%.

column2: and eleven elementary school sites.As of 2016 there are about 2

column1: The construction of this junior high relieved Louise-Michel
column2: which saw its student population decline from about 1
column3: 200 in 2004 to over 500 in 2012.The sole senior high school/sixth form college in Clichy is Lycée Alfred-Nobel. As of 2007 the lycée has 1
column4: 100 students. It has an agreement with the Institut d'études politiques de Paris (Sciences-Po) which allows applicants from the school to gain entrance to the university without taking the entrance examination. As of 2007 three students from the lycée had been admitted.
